name: Environmental Sciences
ratingDescription: As far as Lessons go, this is both somewhat weak and a very nice tool to have at your disposal. You aren't playing this in games that are going well, but it can pull you out of mana screw if you have enough cheap learn cards. I very much want access to one of these in any deck that is capable of learning.

name: Expanded Anatomy
ratingDescription: When you want this effect, it can be quite powerful. Throwing a couple counters on a flyer and getting in for four a turn is not the worst, and only drawing this when it'll be good makes it a Lesson I want access to.

name: Introduction to Annihilation
ratingDescription: Removal you can grab from your sideboard is a valuable tool, even if the rate on this is as bad as we've come to expect from Lessons. Having one of these with a couple learn spells makes you a lot more bomb-proof, which is a nice place to be.

name: Introduction to Prophecy
ratingDescription: This is a slow option, but once again it's good to have the flexibility. This makes all your learn cards into actual card draw, even at a pricey rate.

name: Mascot Exhibition
ratingDescription: Mascot Exhibition is the first Lesson that made me really pay attention in class. Having this as an option gives you a lot of power, and you can build a deck that reliably learns and casts a seven-drop as its finishing move.

name: Wandering Archaic // Explore the Vastlands
ratingDescription: Wandering Archaic is a really annoying card to play against, as it basically taxes all instants and sorceries by two. That's a pretty good ability on a five-mana 4/4, and I'd be happy to play this in any deck. There's a rumor that it has a flip side, but I can't verify it, as paying three mana for a completely symmetrical effect seems so bad that it can't be real.

name: Wandering Archaic // Explore the Vastlands
ratingDescription: Wandering Archaic is a really annoying card to play against, as it basically taxes all instants and sorceries by two. That's a pretty good ability on a five-mana 4/4, and I'd be happy to play this in any deck. There's a rumor that it has a flip side, but I can't verify it, as paying three mana for a completely symmetrical effect seems so bad that it can't be real.

name: Ageless Guardian
ratingDescription: If you need a two-mana 1/4, well, here you are. This is a good defensive body out of the sideboard, but sets are powerful enough these days that cards like this have aged poorly.

name: Beaming Defiance
ratingDescription: As far as tricks go, this is a solid one. It'll win you most fights and stop removal spells in their tracks. At two mana, I'm not excited, but it's a fine playable.

name: Clever Lumimancer
ratingDescription: This has some pretty wild applications for Constructed

name: Combat Professor
ratingDescription: Combat Professor can teach itself, so this already attacks as a 3/3 flying vigilance. That's not bad for four mana, and the ability to send your biggest creature over and still have it be available for blocks is enticing.

name: Defend the Campus
ratingDescription: I really like cards like this. Defend the Campus offers two narrow effects, making it powerful in a couple situations. You either get to kill their one big creature or win big combats if you have a lot of creatures on board, both of which can come up with relative frequency. The main trick here is to make sure you actually have a lot of creatures in your deck. Once you do, this becomes a strong addition.

name: Detention Vortex
ratingDescription: I read this like three times to make sure I wasn't missing something – it felt like I was the one in detention. This card is

name: Dueling Coach
ratingDescription: Dueling Coach is the kind of card that looks like it can take over a game, but instead just promises more than it delivers. It can target itself, making it a 3/3 for four at worst, but I don't think most games will be slow enough for you to really get an edge from this. Plus, the Coach couldn't look dorkier, so I gotta dock it points for that too.

name: Eager First-Year
ratingDescription: If you want a

name: Elite Spellbinder
ratingDescription: This isn't as elite as Paulo Vitor Damo da Rosa, whose likeness it bears, since he's clearly a 5.0 when it comes to Magic. That said, this is still a 3/1 flyer for three that disrupts them, making it a great early pick.

name: Expel
ratingDescription: Expel is a strong defensive card, which isn't something every white deck wants. It kills the creature before it gets to hit you and exiling is always a nice bonus.

name: Guiding Voice
ratingDescription: This is exactly the type of learning I'm not in for. Guiding Voice is not close to being worth a card on its own, and there are no Lessons (or even combination of Lessons) that make it a card I want to play.

name: Mavinda, Students' Advocate
ratingDescription: Mavinda is a nice little flyer by itself and it works out quite well with pump spells. Note that you can use it on the opponent's turn, though only on instants. Those are what work most naturally with the card, and this makes the opponent's life very difficult. You basically have a face-up hand full of combat tricks, so even the threat of them is valuable. I suppose in the super lategame this can also start casting removal, but I don't think that's a big part of the card.

name: Pilgrim of the Ages
ratingDescription: I'm really looking forward to playing with Pilgrim of the Ages. It replaces itself immediately, gets you to the six mana you need to start buying it back and sounds like the perfect way for a control deck to get really obnoxious. I suspect the play pattern here might get a bit repetitive, but it's exactly what I want to be doing.

name: Pillardrop Rescuer
ratingDescription: I'm digging all this white card advantage at common, much like this digs up small creatures. Pillardrop Rescuer is solid top-end for any deck with small to medium creatures and it works especially well if you can get some with nice ETB abilities.

name: Professor of Symbology
ratingDescription: Professor of Symbology is a great card if you have any decent Lessons to teach, and at worst it's a 2/1 that lets you rummage. I'd be in for taking this early and would look to pick up some decent curriculum to make it into a 2/1 that draws a card.

name: Reduce to Memory
ratingDescription: Spirit Within is actually one of the better Lessons you could learn. That may sound weird, given that I spent probably hours of my time on stream explaining why Ravenform sucked, but therein lies the power of Lessons. This card gets to chill in your sideboard until you run into the spot where it’s good, costing you very little in the process. This effect can definitely be strong, and not having to waste a draw on this when it isn’t good is a really solid upside. NOTE: These comments are all for sideboard / Learn synergies – do not play this card in your main deck (the same applies to all Lessons unless stated otherwise).

name: Secret Rendezvous
ratingDescription: Unless you find yourself playing Commander, this is not a card I'd advise putting anywhere close to your deck.

name: Show of Confidence
ratingDescription: Magecraft storm is a cute unwritten mechanic, and Show of Confidence can lead to some nice turns in the right deck. Most of the time this is going to be too much work for +2/+2 or +3/+3, but I'm confident that some decks will be able to live the dream.

name: Sparring Regimen
ratingDescription: Even without the Learn part, Sparring Regimen would be quite strong. It grows a creature quickly and lets it defend, which will really run away with the game if you play it on turn three (preferably after a two-drop). Picking up a Lesson for free doesn't hurt, and this is a fantastic card overall.

name: Star Pupil
ratingDescription: If this is the Star Pupil, no wonder Strixhaven is losing to [totally not] Voldemort (note that I don't know the storyline past what I've seen on the flavor text, so I'm just guessing here). This is not a strong card by itself, and only really aggressive decks or decks trying to go nuts with sacrifice and counter synergies will be interested.

name: Stonebinder's Familiar
ratingDescription: In a deck full of Lorehold (RW) exile nonsense, this can grow somewhat reliably. That doesn't make it great, just passable, since it starts at such a small size.

name: Stonerise Spirit
ratingDescription: Stonerise Spirit isn't big enough to justify the expensive activated ability and I'd only consider running it if I had a ton of cards that keyed off exiling (like Stonebinder's Familiar).

name: Strict Proctor
ratingDescription: If you don't have any cards this disrupts, this is a fairly strong addition to your deck. A 1/3 flyer for two isn't a bad deal, and the odds that it messes with your opponent are pretty high. It's a shame you won't always know how much damage it's doing, as the opponent may just not play cards that it's shutting off.

name: Study Break
ratingDescription: Study Break is another card teaching me lessons I'm not interested in learning. This is too weak of an effect to really be interesting, though it does just enough that I could see playing it if I had an incredible suite of Lesson options.

name: Thunderous Orator
ratingDescription: A 2/2 vigilance for two that snipes flying from time to time is pretty sweet, and this seems like a great way to curve out in a white aggro deck. Plus, every now and then it'll grab some other ability and be a real beast.

name: Arcane Subtraction
ratingDescription: I don't mind a little addition by subtraction, and this is a decent way to learn some Lessons. If you can reliably get into combat, this can be a solid two-for-one.

name: Archmage Emeritus
ratingDescription: The biggest drawback on the Archmage is that it's small and prone to death. The upside is that if they don't kill it, you'll win the game in a landslide. This is definitely great to start with and well worth building around.

name: Burrog Befuddler
ratingDescription: I guess blue gets a common that reduces power from here on out, which I'm honestly okay with. Cards like these always play better than they look, and this will often pick up a nice two-for-one.

name: Bury in Books
ratingDescription: I'd always play this in a defensive deck, and sometimes play it even in a more aggressive one. Getting to put back a creature for just three mana is a good deal, and you can maneuver the game to make it cost less even when you're attacking. Plus, the flavor is on point.

name: Curate
ratingDescription: Curate is going to be the kind of card that you never really have room for, at least in most decks. The exception is when you have a bunch of magecraft cards, as it then becomes a good way to get an extra trigger going, and it gives you a bit of card smoothing while you're at it.

name: Divide by Zero
ratingDescription: The name on this is fantastic, and the effect is solid too. Assuming you have a couple decent Lessons, this is a bounce spell that leaves you up a card, which I'm quite happy paying three mana for.

name: Dream Strix
ratingDescription: Dream Strix does its job admirably. It's not exactly a nightmare for your opponent, as they can likely kill it without much trouble, but dying only to spells means it's at least trading for something. It then gets you a Lesson or a rummage, making this one of the easiest two-for-ones you can find. Plus, sometimes they don't have an answer and it just hits them for 12 or more damage.

name: Frost Trickster
ratingDescription: Frost Trickster is no joke. A flying Frost Lynx is certainly pushed, and this has to be in the running for best common. Even if blue decks don't end up being aggressive, this stops beatdowns as well as starting them, making it a good card no matter what you're up to.

name: Ingenious Mastery
ratingDescription: It takes some kind of mastery to understand what this card is even doing, but once you've figured that out, it's pretty good. It's an expensive card draw spell that offers a cheaper buyout of giving the opponent some scrys and Treasure, which you'll want to try and avoid if possible. This looks best for controlling decks, as it really starts to get interesting around six or seven mana.

name: Kelpie Guide
ratingDescription: I like Kelpie Guide a lot. It initially acts as a mana accelerant, as untapping lands is mainly what it's going to do (though it can also untap blockers as a deterrent). Eventually it graduates to full tapper status, and both modes are well worth three mana.

name: Mentor's Guidance
ratingDescription: I can't imagine it's particularly difficult to end up with one of the spellcasting creature types in play (that seems like the thematic connection to me). Once you do, this is a Divination with scry 2, which I'm obviously in for. You do want to make sure you're copying this almost every time, as three mana to scry 1 and draw one isn't a good deal.

name: Mercurial Transformation
ratingDescription: This being a sorcery really kills it. Even as a Lesson, this is so narrow that you can barely see it, and not something I really anticipating getting.

name: Multiple Choice
ratingDescription: Strixhaven really nails the test-taking theme, as understanding what these cards do is quite challenging. Multiple Choice is a strong one once you figure it out, as it offers a bunch of powerful effects stapled together. You even have the option to pay less mana and get just one of them, though most of the time this will be a five mana 4/4 that bounces, scrys and draws (which is a great deal).

name: Pop Quiz
ratingDescription: I'm bumping most cantrips up a little bit in this set because triggering magecraft is a real benefit. This is a “draw two” if you have good Lessons, and worth playing once you do.

name: Reject
ratingDescription: I've never been a fan of situational counterspells in Limited. Counterspells are already dicey, given that leaving mana up is a real cost, and having this not always work is brutal. Sometimes they just cast a sorcery on turn four and this rots in your hand. Other times you top-deck this on turn eight and it never does anything. It's going to get a card often enough that it's fine to play, but I'd reject it in a lot of my decks.

name: Resculpt
ratingDescription: The joke here is that you turn your crappy token or Treasure into a 4/4, but that's a lot of hoops to jump through to get a card you can usually pay around four or five mana for. Using it on their permanent is asking for trouble, and overall this is a card not worth trying to build.

name: Serpentine Curve
ratingDescription: This gets high marks if you grade it on a curve, as the only decks interested in playing it will make it look pretty good. If you have 10 or more spells, this is a large creature that makes all your other spells-matter cards better, which I'm in for.

name: Snow Day
ratingDescription: I love the combination of card draw plus tempo, and Snow Day offers both in spades. This buys you time and card selection, making it a good play when ahead or behind. It's expensive, so you can't just jam a ton of them, but the first one will be really good.

name: Solve the Equation
ratingDescription: Here's an equation for you to solve: the casting cost of any instant or sorcery + 3 = way too much mana.

name: Soothsayer Adept
ratingDescription: Paying two mana to loot is a lot, and you can't activate this more than once or twice and really expect to win. That said, it's a decent early blocker that has relevance in the lategame, so I'm not opposed to playing one.

name: Symmetry Sage
ratingDescription: In a spell-heavy deck, this plays like a 2/2 flyer enough of the time to be worth including. Plus, every now and then it'll make a 1/1 into a 2/1, which isn't very symmetrical (but can be good in combat).

name: Teachings of the Archaics
ratingDescription: It's hard to make this work, but a situational card that offers power in the right spot is a good Lesson. I like this in more aggressive decks, as you can empty your hand and try and get two or even three cards from it.

name: Tempted by the Oriq
ratingDescription: The mana cost may be a bit rough, but I'm tempted to include this in any blue deck that can support it. Stealing a creature, even a small one, is a huge swing, and well worth stretching the ol' mana base.

name: Test of Talents
ratingDescription: This is basically a more narrow Negate, and Negate was already a sideboard card. This will be fine against magecraft decks, but not worth main-decking in hopes of running into them.

name: Vortex Runner
ratingDescription: I'm a fan of the eight lands theme, as I plan on getting to eight lands most games myself. Vortex Runner is a fine blocker early, mediocre midgame and very strong once you've activated its trap card.

name: Waterfall Aerialist
ratingDescription: Aggressive decks are going to love the Aerialist, as it punishes removal spells quite well. It's soft to combat, but flyers get around most fights and being resistant to removal is good upside.

name: Wormhole Serpent
ratingDescription: Wormhole Serpent offers a mediocre stat line and overpriced ability, which do combine into a passable card if you are short on finishers.

name: Arrogant Poet
ratingDescription: In an aggressive deck, this does a great job of filling in the gaps. It attacks well enough in the early game, and later lets you trade two-for-two, which will often be worth it. I have the image of the poet running up to people on the street and reciting his poems to an unwilling audience.

name: Baleful Mastery
ratingDescription: This is unconditional removal for just four mana, and it even offers a two-mana version in a pinch. That's good in my book, and I'm happy taking this early.

name: Brackish Trudge
ratingDescription: Brackish Trudge may be slow, but it's inexorable. The opponent won't want to block this, and anytime it trades off is a big success. It's also good sacrifice fodder and overall is a great finisher or early play alike.

name: Callous Bloodmage
ratingDescription: Callous Bloodmage gets you good value no matter what you do with it, with the top two abilities being the most common selection. A Pest, a card and sometimes graveyard removal – all of these are worth stapling to a cheap 2/1.

name: Confront the Past
ratingDescription: This card is about as narrow as it gets, requiring a planeswalker on either side of the board to be useful. I suppose being a Lesson gives it a shot, and I wouldn't mind having access to this if I had a good planeswalker to bring back.

name: Crushing Disappointment
ratingDescription: Four mana is one more mana than I like to pay for this effect (Divination Gang for life), but at least this pings the opponent for two while it's at it. I would look to play this in decks with a low curve, as they'll make the most of the life loss while having the time to pay four for a pair of new cards.

name: Essence Infusion
ratingDescription: Sorcery speed combat tricks are

name: Eyetwitch
ratingDescription: I'm actually in for Eyetwitch. A 1/1 flyer that you can eventually cash in for a Lesson or a rummage is a good deal in the right deck. This provides a little aggression, some sacrifice fodder and some card selection, which is well worth the low cost of one mana.

name: Flunk
ratingDescription: The flavor here is perfect – if you do the math wrong, you'll definitely flunk the game. This will mostly give -3/-3 or greater for two mana, which is a fantastic deal, and will kill anything you need it to (within reason).

name: Go Blank
ratingDescription: If you want a Mind Rot, you've got one. Most formats aren't Mind Rot formats these days, and Strixhaven likely won't be either, but this effect tends to be great in Sealed and after sideboarding against slow decks.

name: Hunt for Specimens
ratingDescription: I like this one as well. Learning Lessons seems solid to me, and with a little work, this is a build-your-own Elvish Visionary, which is not a bad place to be.

name: Lash of Malice
ratingDescription: Lash will play as a Shock 99 percent of the time, which is more than fine. Every now and then it'll let you pump your own creature, so be on the lookout for those opportunities (as well as watching out for combat tricks which punish you in response to trying to kill something).

name: Leech Fanatic
ratingDescription: More like Leech Fantastic, am I right? This is a fine two-drop as far as two-drops go, and I'd be happy filling out the curve with this any day.

name: Mage Hunter
ratingDescription: Mage Hunter has solid stats and an annoying recurring ping ability, which makes it a good midrange threat.

name: Mage Hunters' Onslaught
ratingDescription: This is playable in any deck as four-mana removal and absolutely gross in aggressive ones. Killing their biggest blocker and threatening an additional couple damage is awesome, making this premium removal for beatdown decks.

name: Necrotic Fumes
ratingDescription: I would strive to play this as a Lesson and not in your main deck, but some decks will be happy just running it. This is a great addition to decks that generate lots of Pests, and it's a removal spell you'll often be able to pick up late (since it stinks in decks that aren't trying to enable it).

name: Novice Dissector
ratingDescription: Getting killed by a Novice Dissector sounds like a messy way to go, but I don't imagine it'll happen too often. This ability is fine if you have enough fodder, but most decks won't really view this as much more than a 3/3 for four, which is below the curve these days.

name: Oriq Loremage
ratingDescription: Oriq Loremage grows itself nicely, and most decks will be able to feed it a couple nice spells at least. It does thin your deck out of action, but that's well worth getting a 5/5 or 6/6 in exchange.

name: Plumb the Forbidden
ratingDescription: The title evokes the experience of clogging a toilet at a friend's house, which is not a pleasant experience (or so I've heard). You have to be pretty deep in tokens to make this really pop off, but even sacrificing one creature makes it a bad Night's Whisper. There are enough Pests around that this has potential, and you should be the only person at the table that wants it when you're in the right deck.

name: Professor Onyx
ratingDescription: Professor Onyx checks all the boxes I'm looking for in a planeswalker. She has a ton of loyalty, draws cards and can remove their best creature. There's not much else you need, and the magecraft trigger is a strong addition as well.

name: Professor's Warning
ratingDescription: This trick is flexible enough to warrant a spot in most creature-heavy decks, as it shrugs off removal, can help win fights and has the mana cost I'm looking for. It's also a great way to get an unexpected magecraft trigger.

name: Promising Duskmage
ratingDescription: I don't want to go through the effort of giving this a counter and making sure it dies to get my card back, which makes me think the name is really overselling it. Is this really the best Silverquill has to offer?

name: Sedgemoor Witch
ratingDescription: Sedgemoor Witch is fantastic. For just three mana, you get a menace threat that pings them for three if they want to kill it, and it even generates a steady stream of Pest tokens. This is quite the aggressive Young Pyromancer, and I'm completely in – the Moor the merrier.

name: Specter of the Fens
ratingDescription: This will likely end up playing out a bit like Dread Rider – a slightly overcosted creature that's very capable of ending games. Paying six to drain the opponent is pricey, but you can put them on a fast clock and gaining two helps mitigate all the mana you're spending. I'm not thrilled by the prospect of playing this all the time, but I bet it does better than it looks.

name: Tenured Inkcaster
ratingDescription: Tenured Inkcaster is going to do a lot of good work in decks that are built to maximize it, as it triggers for each attacking creature (and spots you the first one on the house). It's solid without much support and one of your best cards if you can reliably put two or three creatures into play with counters.

name: Umbral Juke
ratingDescription: I'm here for the name, as juking them is an awesome concept. This also lives up to that flavor, as it crushes the opponent if they're on just one big creature, and gives you a decent buyout of a 2/1 flyer if they have too much small stuff. That flexibility makes this work, even if neither ability is amazing.

name: Unwilling Ingredient
ratingDescription: I kinda like this plucky little guy. Unwilling Ingredient will get in for a couple points before chumping or being sacrificed, and later in the game gives you your card back. This is the kind of card that thrives in synergy decks and I have high hopes for it.

name: Academic Dispute
ratingDescription: Academic Dispute is not a bad way to teach one of their creatures a lesson, especially if you have decently-sized creatures. If this all works out the way you want, it's a two-for-one, and even if your creatures trade, you do get a card back. Just make sure to only attack with one creature, as they don't have to block a specific thing, just block in general. This also works as a way to give your creature reach and block a flyer, thanks to being an instant.

name: Ardent Dustspeaker
ratingDescription: By the time this attacks, you probably have enough mana to cast multiple cards, making this trigger suspiciously close to a draw two. That's a pretty sweet deal, even if you have to have enough spells to make it reliably work.

name: Blood Age General
ratingDescription: In a deck with few Spirits, this is a Grizzly Bear with minor upside – that's generally playable in aggressive decks. In a Spirit-heavy deck, this is awesome, as you're paying very little for this ability.

name: Conspiracy Theorist
ratingDescription: Conspiracy Theorist is best with a lot of mana, but even on turn three can bear fruit. A two-drop that draws you a card when it attacks is worth listening to any amount of unhinged rants. At the end of the day, a card is a card, even if you have to sit through a lecture about how Treefolk are the real culprits behind mana shortages or whatever.

name: Crackle with Power
ratingDescription: This card is pretty hard to understand, but at five mana (X=1), it deals five damage to one target, and for eight mana, it's dealing 10 damage to two targets. That's a good deal, as 3RR to deal five to one thing is a decent floor, and there's a lot of upside if you can get to eight or 11 mana.

name: Draconic Intervention
ratingDescription: In a deck that has a lot of expensive spells, particularly ones you can discard for Treasure, this is a sweeper that has some element of choice to it (you won't always be able to dictate how much damage it deals, but sometimes you can). That means you can set it up, and maybe have a big creature or Dragon survive, which is a good bit of advantage. This is tricky to use, but powerful enough to do some work for.

name: Dragon's Approach
ratingDescription: There are so many problems with this, I don't know where to start. It does nothing by itself, requires FIVE copies to even have an effect and you need a Dragon to make it a payoff. Approach with caution.

name: Efreet Flamepainter
ratingDescription: I like the upside here, but I'm having trouble painting the picture it promises. You need a trick or a lot of removal to get this through, and once you do, you get a free spell. If you used removal, that at least works out nicely, but you'll need more than combat tricks to make this worthwhile. It's still a 2/4 for four with upside, but it won't go off as often as you might hope.

name: Enthusiastic Study
ratingDescription: There's some good value to be had with strong study habits (or so I'm told), and this can be a decent way to impart some learning. Aggressive decks that have a good selection of Lessons will want this, and most every other deck will not.

name: Explosive Welcome
ratingDescription: Eight mana has to pretty much win you the game in Limited to be worth it, and this decidedly does not. I like the idea, but unless you have a lot of mana acceleration, leave the warm welcomes in the sideboard.

name: Fervent Mastery
ratingDescription: I'm not sure what this is trying to accomplish, but Limited isn't the place to do it. You'll rarely get any edge from this, and even if it works perfectly, you still spent five mana to not affect the board or even be up any cards.

name: First Day of Class
ratingDescription: I hate cards that give haste and cost mana, even as little as two. It just so rarely does anything that it might as well be flavor text, and the +1/+1 counter doesn't help much. Learn is nice at least, but overall this isn't enough of a card to justify itself (it does have good flavor though).

name: Fuming Effigy
ratingDescription: A 4/3 for four doesn't have to do too much to justify itself, and this will ping the opponent once or twice a game in most red-white decks. That's about the bare minimum needed to make the cut, but make the cut this will.

name: Grinning Ignus
ratingDescription: Grinning Ignus isn't good enough by itself, as a Grey Ogre that can ramp you is not going to really deliver much value. Where this gets interesting is if you have some spectacular high-end cards (which Prismari often does), or if you're really trying to get magecraft going by playing multiple spells in the same turn. For the most part, you can do better, but when this does its thing, it'll leave you with a smile on your face.

name: Hall Monitor
ratingDescription: This card is clearly just here because the name is so good, and I can totally respect that. The actual card is not quite as strong, as a 1/1 haste isn't much and paying two mana to temporarily remove a blocker isn't efficient.

name: Heated Debate
ratingDescription: You don't have to be a math genius to figure out that three mana for four damage is good, especially at instant speed. Being uncounterable is just a bonus, and one that matters more than usual thanks to ward.

name: Igneous Inspiration
ratingDescription: In a deck with good Lessons, this is awesome. You get to take out a creature for three mana and be up a card in the exchange. Note that this can hit the opponent, so it's even a finisher of sorts.

name: Illuminate History
ratingDescription: This is the exact kind of Lesson I want access to. It's not good until fairly late in the game, but being able to exchange a couple lands or dead cards for new ones and make a 3/2 is a powerful ability to have access to. When this isn't good, you can just pick a different Lesson or rummage, and having that optionality is one of the strengths of this mechanic.

name: Illustrious Historian
ratingDescription: While I do like two-drops that are relevant later, this sort of effect isn't quite as good as it looks. It's still a solid inclusion in an aggro deck, but a five-mana 3/2 isn't going to save you when things go south.

name: Mascot Interception
ratingDescription: I'm just so over Threaten effects in Limited at this point. I've come to accept that red-black sac just isn't a thing anymore, and given that it isn't even a supported color pair in this set, I don't see where this really fits.

name: Pigment Storm
ratingDescription: Five for five, the classic deal. You'll almost always play this and never be too happy with it, though Prismari has a bunch of cards that make expensive spells a little more appealing. Getting to “trample” over for a few points isn't bad either, and this can act as a pseudo-Lava Axe by nugging a 1/1.

name: Pillardrop Warden
ratingDescription: I'm kind of liking this as a defensive option for a heavy spells deck. It blocks for a while, sitting on top of its mountain, then grabs a spell back once you no longer need its services. Not every deck will want it, but it definitely seems to have a home.

name: Retriever Phoenix
ratingDescription: There is some funny flavor here – instead of learning, you just get to summon a kick-ass bird instead. I'm in for that, as the Phoenix is a strong recurring threat, and it even lets you grab a lesson the first time you play it. Ideally you have a couple learn triggers in your deck, and I'm rating this as if you have at least two.

name: Start from Scratch
ratingDescription: This is never going to be an exciting Lesson to learn, but it does trade for an artifact or small creature. That gives it some functionality, and I'd pick one up for the sideboard if you can get it at low cost.

name: Storm-Kiln Artist
ratingDescription: In a dedicated spells deck, this can generate a lot of mana (and be a decent threat on its own). That helps string multiple spells together on the same turn, or just build up to a big spell, which is the kind of engine card I'm interested in.

name: Sudden Breakthrough
ratingDescription: Decks that want combat tricks aren't usually that much in need of mana ramp, so this card is a bit scattered. That said, it will let creatures punch above their weight class, and in a magecraft deck, could definitely make the cut.

name: Tome Shredder
ratingDescription: In a deck with seven or more spells to eat, Tome Shredder is a solid little threat (and the more spells you have, the more threatening it becomes). It also plays nicely with the Lorehold theme of exiling, and can make any instant into a combat trick. The haste really sells me, as this can start growing immediately.

name: Twinscroll Shaman
ratingDescription: Double strike is a nice way to get paid off for combat tricks, so I'm happy playing Twinscroll in any aggro deck that has a few ways to pump it.

name: Accomplished Alchemist
ratingDescription: Accomplished Alchemist is certainly accomplished enough even without life gain, as a four-mana 2/5 is pretty beefy, and tapping for one mana is a nice upside. Sometimes this will tap for a couple mana or more, but that's not a big part of the card overall.

name: Basic Conjuration
ratingDescription: As far as Lessons go, this is a slow one. It's like a college lecture that's gone on for hours, and everyone is on the verge of falling asleep – not an experience I want during a game of Magic. Having to get this from a learn card and then cast it to find a creature is one hoop too many, and I wouldn't prioritize this in the draft.

name: Bayou Groff
ratingDescription: A 5/4 for five with upside is not a bad card, and the upside here is that sometimes you just straight-up kill your opponent. In Witherbloom, turn one Eyetwitch or Unwilling Ingredient into Groff is really tough to handle, and a play I'd be happy to make. In a deck with no possibility of casting it for two mana, this gets worse for sure, but most decks will be able to live the dream at least some of the time.

name: Big Play
ratingDescription: I love that green has a bunch of sports metaphors in this set, because it's new flavor that we haven't really seen in Magic. This card is also solid, giving you a big burst immediately and having some of it stick around. If you're in for combat tricks, this is a solid one.

name: Bookwurm
ratingDescription: This gets a build-around rating because you can't really put eight-drops into normal decks. As far as eight-drops go, this is one that actually interests me. It gains you three and draws a card, making it a powerful play that does some amount of catching you up, and it gives you complete inevitability thanks to the recursion effect. Most decks won't want this, but it's nice having such a good win condition for the extreme ramp decks, and you won't have to take this early to pick one up.

name: Charge Through
ratingDescription: Cards like this rarely end up making the final cut, but magecraft goes a long way. Because of that, Charge Through will have more utility than normal, despite the minor effect.

name: Containment Breach
ratingDescription: This is exactly the kind of Lesson I want in my sideboard, and I don't mind taking it somewhat early as a result. Having a good answer to problem cards that you never have to draw is nice, and this does precisely what I was hoping Lessons would do.

name: Devouring Tendrils
ratingDescription: I'll take a bite out of crime with this, as you get to kill a creature and gain a few life. Note the creature doesn't fight back, making this a decent amount safe and easier to use than a fight card.

name: Dragonsguard Elite
ratingDescription: The Elite grows rapidly and threatens to double up in the lategame, which makes it a premium two-drop. You don't have to do tons of work to make this solid, and it becomes great in a heavy spells deck.

name: Ecological Appreciation
ratingDescription: As much as I appreciate some nice card advantage, this is a tough one to make work. For six mana, you get your third and fourth best three-drops, and so on. You usually won't want to cast this for X=2, so we're talking six or seven mana as the most likely outputs. That requires you to have a lot of cards at those costs for the third and fourth best ones to be good, and for you not to have drawn too many of these (though it does look at graveyards too). This doesn't strike me as a good enough deal, and between the situational nature and cost, I think I'll pass.

name: Emergent Sequence
ratingDescription: If you play a land then cast this, you get a 2/2 for two that taps for the color of your choice, which is a great deal. Sometimes it may only be a 1/1, but even then it's a card I'm happy to play.

name: Exponential Growth
ratingDescription: At sorcery speed, this is going to make an impressively large creature that just gets chump blocked. It's cute how big this can grow things, but unless you're on the all-trample deck and the opponent has no instants, it won't accomplish much.

name: Field Trip
ratingDescription: I love taking field trips, and this one comes with a free lunch too. You get to ramp a little, learn a Lesson and be up a card when all is said and done, which is a card worth spending three mana on.

name: Fortifying Draught
ratingDescription: At +2/+2 and two life for one mana, this is a perfectly serviceable trick. It has the potential to do a little more, but that won't come up all that often.

name: Gnarled Professor
ratingDescription: Now this is a gnarly way to learn. Professor Oak here is a monstrously large creature for just four mana and it imparts some wisdom on the way in. This is great without any Lessons to grab, and even better once you have a couple.

name: Honor Troll
ratingDescription: The life gain theme in Witherbloom isn't pronounced enough to be worth going to great lengths to enable, so cards like this aren't all that high a priority for me. The name is the best thing this has going for it, though it's a fine card to play if you have a couple sources of life gain.

name: Karok Wrangler
ratingDescription: The name of the game here is untapping with the Wrangler, as its magecraft ability is quite strong. It makes combat a nightmare for the opponent, and grows your creatures rapidly and cheaply. You often won't make it to your turn with this in play, but when you do, things tend to go well.

name: Leyline Invocation
ratingDescription: A giant Fractal for six mana isn't quite what the doctor ordered, as it's susceptible to bounce and doesn't have any keywords (like, say, trample). Still, if you need top end, this does fit the bill.

name: Mage Duel
ratingDescription: Mage Duel is both powerful and efficient, words that are highly correlated with getting a good grade. This would be worth it at three mana, as +1/+2 means your creature basically always wins the fight, and getting a discount some of the time is just gravy.

name: Master Symmetrist
ratingDescription: I'm in for a 4/4 for four with reach and trample, and this even offers a tiny bit more. It gives all your Fractals trample, as well as any other square-statted creature you have lying about, and I'm sure it'll pick up plenty of free cards based on not looking like something with reach.

name: Overgrown Arch
ratingDescription: The Arch has a combination of abilities that's just golden, so you could definitely say I'm lovin' it. It blocks well and gains life, then eventually turns into another card once you have the mana to utilize a Lesson (or the need for a specific one). That's a deal for two mana that makes me quite happy.

name: Professor of Zoomancy
ratingDescription: Four mana is a fair price for this many stats across two bodies, especially given the sacrifice theme in Witherbloom.

name: Reckless Amplimancer
ratingDescription: This is mostly just a 2/2 for two, which some decks are in for. The ability is expensive enough and anemic enough that I don't really count it as lategame action, though if you can pump this before using it, maybe it gets there.

name: Scurrid Colony
ratingDescription: Having reach makes this slightly better than your average Bear, and in the lategame it becomes a bit of a brawler. That works for me, and I'd play this in most decks.

name: Spined Karok
ratingDescription: The stats here don't really justify the cost, as a vanilla creature that's mostly good on defense doesn't tend to help you win games.

name: Springmane Cervin
ratingDescription: Gaining two life makes this a little more useful than it would be otherwise, but it's still mostly a dork.

name: Tangletrap
ratingDescription: I'm happy sideboarding this, though it's a lot less of a priority if you can pick up some good Lessons as your artifact/enchantment interaction instead.

name: Verdant Mastery
ratingDescription: Six mana for two lands in play and two in hand is way too much, as you don't need ramp once you're at six. The four cost version gives you two in play, one in hand, and ramps the opponent for one, which I'm also pretty skeptical of. They get first crack at the mana, and didn't have to spend a card, making this a bad idea overall.

name: Augmenter Pugilist // Echoing Equation
ratingDescription: This is worth playing in mono-green, as a 3/3 trample that turns into a Force of Nature is pretty sweet. The blue half is also a nice situational card, as it can act as an Overrun if you have the right set of creatures.

name: Augmenter Pugilist // Echoing Equation
ratingDescription: This is worth playing in mono-green, as a 3/3 trample that turns into a Force of Nature is pretty sweet. The blue half is also a nice situational card, as it can act as an Overrun if you have the right set of creatures.

name: Blex, Vexing Pest // Search for Blex
ratingDescription: Blex offers two complimentary effects, which makes it a strong addition to any Witherbloom deck. The life cost may be steep on Search for Blex, but having it as an option for games where you aren't under pressure is quite strong.

name: Blex, Vexing Pest // Search for Blex
ratingDescription: Blex offers two complimentary effects, which makes it a strong addition to any Witherbloom deck. The life cost may be steep on Search for Blex, but having it as an option for games where you aren't under pressure is quite strong.

name: Extus, Oriq Overlord // Awaken the Blood Avatar
ratingDescription: Both sides of this are quite strong, though Extus is both stronger and in a supported color pair, making it the start of the show. For just four mana, you get a sizable creature and a recurring way to get creatures back, making this a must-kill that can hold its own in a fight. Awaken the Blood Avatar is a worthy splash as well, though I wouldn't bend over backwards to do so in a deck without good sacrifice fodder.

name: Extus, Oriq Overlord // Awaken the Blood Avatar
ratingDescription: Both sides of this are quite strong, though Extus is both stronger and in a supported color pair, making it the start of the show. For just four mana, you get a sizable creature and a recurring way to get creatures back, making this a must-kill that can hold its own in a fight. Awaken the Blood Avatar is a worthy splash as well, though I wouldn't bend over backwards to do so in a deck without good sacrifice fodder.

name: Flamescroll Celebrant // Revel in Silence
ratingDescription: Celebrant is basically just a red card, as Revel in Silence isn't a card you'll cast in most games. It offers a good aggressive two-drop that has lategame power, which is definitely enough to make the cut.

name: Flamescroll Celebrant // Revel in Silence
ratingDescription: Celebrant is basically just a red card, as Revel in Silence isn't a card you'll cast in most games. It offers a good aggressive two-drop that has lategame power, which is definitely enough to make the cut.

name: Jadzi, Oracle of Arcavios // Journey to the Oracle
ratingDescription: This is another eight-drop that offers power at great cost, though it's probably a worse finisher than Bookwurm. It doesn't do much the turn you play it, and even after you untap, you need spells to make it work. The flip side is really bad too, making this a card I'm unlikely to play.

name: Jadzi, Oracle of Arcavios // Journey to the Oracle
ratingDescription: This is another eight-drop that offers power at great cost, though it's probably a worse finisher than Bookwurm. It doesn't do much the turn you play it, and even after you untap, you need spells to make it work. The flip side is really bad too, making this a card I'm unlikely to play.

name: Kianne, Dean of Substance // Imbraham, Dean of Theory
ratingDescription: The rating here is mostly for the blue side, though I'd play this in either blue or green (and it's fantastic if you're both colors). Both Deans give you a lot of long-game power, and do so at a very reasonable cost.

name: Kianne, Dean of Substance // Imbraham, Dean of Theory
ratingDescription: The rating here is mostly for the blue side, though I'd play this in either blue or green (and it's fantastic if you're both colors). Both Deans give you a lot of long-game power, and do so at a very reasonable cost.

name: Mila, Crafty Companion // Lukka, Wayward Bonder
ratingDescription: Both Mila and Lukka are worth playing individually, and Lukka especially is good on his own. These aren't in bomb territory, but Mila's card draw effect and Lukka's high loyalty make these worth running. If you treat them both as card advantage engines more than board presence, you'll be on the right track.

name: Mila, Crafty Companion // Lukka, Wayward Bonder
ratingDescription: Both Mila and Lukka are worth playing individually, and Lukka especially is good on his own. These aren't in bomb territory, but Mila's card draw effect and Lukka's high loyalty make these worth running. If you treat them both as card advantage engines more than board presence, you'll be on the right track.

name: Pestilent Cauldron // Restorative Burst
ratingDescription: The Cauldron offers a lot of action in GB, as you can utilize all the different abilities nicely. I especially like how the Pest-making ability keeps you alive long enough to draw extra cards and eventually mill them out. The flip side is also strong, as it's a two-for-one that gains a bunch of life (even if it gives them some life too).

name: Pestilent Cauldron // Restorative Burst
ratingDescription: The Cauldron offers a lot of action in GB, as you can utilize all the different abilities nicely. I especially like how the Pest-making ability keeps you alive long enough to draw extra cards and eventually mill them out. The flip side is also strong, as it's a two-for-one that gains a bunch of life (even if it gives them some life too).

name: Plargg, Dean of Chaos // Augusta, Dean of Order
ratingDescription: Both sides of the Lorehold Dean are great, and I'd play this for either one. Plargg offers some nice card advantage and filtering while Augusta is a formidable board pump. It's also nice that Plargg helps in games where you're playing control and Augusta when you're attacking, making them a synergistic pair in RW.

name: Plargg, Dean of Chaos // Augusta, Dean of Order
ratingDescription: Both sides of the Lorehold Dean are great, and I'd play this for either one. Plargg offers some nice card advantage and filtering while Augusta is a formidable board pump. It's also nice that Plargg helps in games where you're playing control and Augusta when you're attacking, making them a synergistic pair in RW.

name: Rowan, Scholar of Sparks // Will, Scholar of Frost
ratingDescription: The rating here is mostly for Will, as he's the much stronger side. Getting to negate an attacker while building loyalty towards card drawing and the ultimate is pretty nice, and if you can protect Will for a turn or two he gives you a massive advantage. I wouldn't play this just for Rowan, as she doesn't affect the board nearly enough and doesn't even draw you cards for the trouble.

name: Rowan, Scholar of Sparks // Will, Scholar of Frost
ratingDescription: The rating here is mostly for Will, as he's the much stronger side. Getting to negate an attacker while building loyalty towards card drawing and the ultimate is pretty nice, and if you can protect Will for a turn or two he gives you a massive advantage. I wouldn't play this just for Rowan, as she doesn't affect the board nearly enough and doesn't even draw you cards for the trouble.

name: Selfless Glyphweaver // Deadly Vanity
ratingDescription: The Glyphweaver is a great card on any sort of wide board, and having the flip side of a huge board wipe is really nice. I like this as an eight-drop bomb that you can play early, and it works especially well with Raise Dead effects if you can pick some up.

name: Selfless Glyphweaver // Deadly Vanity
ratingDescription: The Glyphweaver is a great card on any sort of wide board, and having the flip side of a huge board wipe is really nice. I like this as an eight-drop bomb that you can play early, and it works especially well with Raise Dead effects if you can pick some up.

name: Shaile, Dean of Radiance // Embrose, Dean of Shadow
ratingDescription: Shaile is absurd, giving you a Glorious Anthem effect for every creature you play afterwards. Embrose isn't bad either, offering a pump effect or a card draw engine (and sometimes both at once), making this strong even if you can only play one side.

name: Shaile, Dean of Radiance // Embrose, Dean of Shadow
ratingDescription: Shaile is absurd, giving you a Glorious Anthem effect for every creature you play afterwards. Embrose isn't bad either, offering a pump effect or a card draw engine (and sometimes both at once), making this strong even if you can only play one side.

name: Torrent Sculptor // Flamethrower Sonata
ratingDescription: This needs a deck with a lot of spells to be functional, as both sides key off that. That likely does restrict it to Prismari, especially since neither side is all that strong on its own (but having the option of both helps a lot).

name: Torrent Sculptor // Flamethrower Sonata
ratingDescription: This needs a deck with a lot of spells to be functional, as both sides key off that. That likely does restrict it to Prismari, especially since neither side is all that strong on its own (but having the option of both helps a lot).

name: Uvilda, Dean of Perfection // Nassari, Dean of Expression
ratingDescription: Uvilda is quite bad, and I wouldn't plan on casting the blue side as a result. Waiting three turns to get a discount on spells isn't something I'm interested in doing. That said, Nassari is awesome and will win you the game in a landslide if not removed. It draws an extra card every turn, and grows while doing so.

name: Uvilda, Dean of Perfection // Nassari, Dean of Expression
ratingDescription: Uvilda is quite bad, and I wouldn't plan on casting the blue side as a result. Waiting three turns to get a discount on spells isn't something I'm interested in doing. That said, Nassari is awesome and will win you the game in a landslide if not removed. It draws an extra card every turn, and grows while doing so.

name: Valentin, Dean of the Vein // Lisette, Dean of the Root
ratingDescription: Valentin has the dubious distinction of being a card with three conditional “if X happens,” but is still a fine card despite the text box gore. He eats their creatures as they die, and a 1/1 menace lifelink is a nice little beater too. Lisette is also quite strong, and in a life gain deck will dominate the game very quickly.

name: Valentin, Dean of the Vein // Lisette, Dean of the Root
ratingDescription: Valentin has the dubious distinction of being a card with three conditional “if X happens,” but is still a fine card despite the text box gore. He eats their creatures as they die, and a 1/1 menace lifelink is a nice little beater too. Lisette is also quite strong, and in a life gain deck will dominate the game very quickly.

name: Aether Helix
ratingDescription: Aether Helix is a nice 1.5-for-one, as bouncing a creature is good but not quite a whole card. This picks up something good from your bin and gives you the time to cast it, which is not a bad use of five mana. You can even bounce your own thing with an ETB ability if you have the time, making this flexible as well.

name: Beledros Witherbloom
ratingDescription: Beledros is pricey, but worth it. This is a force to be reckoned with, and blooms a verdant army of Pests if not removed immediately. The 10 life ability isn't one I expect to use very often, but it's nice to have – sometimes you're ahead on life and can afford to get an extra turn's worth of mana out of this.

name: Biomathematician
ratingDescription: I really like this, and not just because the name is fun to say. It starts by making a 2/2 and a 1/1, but grows with each additional copy (and works nicely with other Fractal cards). That's a classic “good on its own, great with friends” deal, and I'm here for it.

name: Blade Historian
ratingDescription: Blade Historian is an absolute powerhouse. The turn you play this, you get to make a massive attack, and then it steps and starts taking names itself. It's also trivial to cast in RW, and a big reason to go into those colors if you open it.

name: Blood Researcher
ratingDescription: I like Blood Researcher with as many Pest as there are floating around. Most of the cards that make Pests are pretty good, so I'm willing to do some research and get paid off – a 3/3 menace is no joke.

name: Body of Research
ratingDescription: Size isn't the issue here, as this makes a 20/20 or so (and there isn't much of a difference between a 15/15 and a 25/25). What scares me is the casting cost, as you'll really feel it when you draw this on four Forests and two Islands. Add to that the vulnerability to removal, especially bounce, and you have a card that crushes some matchups but is quite poor in others. I'd still play it, but it's not an enormous bomb (well, it is enormous, but you get the idea).

name: Closing Statement
ratingDescription: My biggest qualm with this card is that you have to set an end of turn stop on Arena when you draw it, and depending on how they do quick autopassing, maybe even before (if you don't have an EOT stop set and you draw this on less than five mana, there's a chance Arena just passes the turn away from you).

name: Cram Session
ratingDescription: This is not the way. Much like actual cram sessions, this will resolve and you'll have very little to show for it.

name: Creative Outburst
ratingDescription: I like the idea of Creative Outburst – for seven mana, you get a powerful effect and you can discard it for a Treasure if you aren't close to casting it. However, a Treasure is definitely not worth a card, so this isn't a cycling card by any stretch, but there are a bunch of ways to take advantage of cards in graveyard, so it's not nothing either. I like this for control decks, especially ones with good spell synergies.

name: Culling Ritual
ratingDescription: Killing all small creatures just isn't that valuable in Limited. Some decks may be vulnerable to this, but most won't be, and I struggle to see this picking up more than a card or two (though it does clean up Pests nicely).

name: Culmination of Studies
ratingDescription: As far as final exams go, this one is pretty hard to pass. For Culmination of Studies to be worthwhile, it needs to draw you like two or three cards, and that's not going to be easy. Unless your deck has an abnormally high number of blue cards, this is not a card I'd look to play.

name: Daemogoth Titan
ratingDescription: First things first – this is unplayable in your average deck. You just can't afford to throw away that many creatures, even if you get a gargantuan one in return. However, in a deck that generates a lot of sacrificial fodder, this can be a real beating. Given enough Pests and Unwilling Ingredients, you can take over the world with Daemogoth Titan. It's also nice that you have control over when this feeds, as you can just not attack or block with it until you have the right setup. I like this as a build-around.

name: Daemogoth Woe-Eater
ratingDescription: I like the Woe-Eater as well, and the buyout clause makes this a lot more flexible. Sometimes it'll just act as a three-for-one on your upkeep, and the opponent won't have much of a window to kill it. Note that it triggers whenever you sacrifice it, so saccing it to some other effect does the trick as well.

name: Deadly Brew
ratingDescription: I'd crack open a cold one any day. This is less an edict effect and more a nice Raise Dead, with the side benefit of trading your worst creature for theirs. In Witherbloom, that's likely to be in your favor, making this a delicious brew indeed. It also gets back any permanent, so you can snag other cards besides creatures if need be.

name: Decisive Denial
ratingDescription: I really like the combination of two vastly different effects here. Fight at instant speed is good most of the time, but when you need a three-point Spell Pierce, this is going to be amazing.

name: Dina, Soul Steeper
ratingDescription: Dina is a nice role-player, as she does need a little help to get going. In the average Witherbloom deck, you'll have fodder and life gain aplenty, making Dina well worth the two mana you spent on her.

name: Double Major
ratingDescription: If you're like me, you initially thought this copied a creature in play. It most certainly does not – it only copies a creature spell on the stack. That makes this really awkward to use, and not a card I recommend playing.

name: Dramatic Finale
ratingDescription: Assuming you're in BW, this is as easy to cast as it gets and has a very powerful effect. It generates a steady stream of tokens, then buffs them, giving you an army of 3/2 fliers in just a couple turns. Even at just one per turn, this is still great, and lives up to its name nicely.

name: Elemental Masterpiece
ratingDescription: Seven mana for two 4/4s is nothing to write home about, and discarding it to make a Treasure doesn't make this into a masterpiece at all. I'd avoid this unless I had good synergies involving the discard.

name: Elemental Summoning
ratingDescription: This is one of the better common Lessons, which says something since it's not all that efficient. It's still definitely worth a whole card, which is all you really need Lessons to be worth.

name: Eureka Moment
ratingDescription: This combines two things that really like going together, as putting lands into play helps you use all the additional cards you've drawn. This fits nicely into the college's theme, and is a powerful card in a ramp deck with a high curve.

name: Exhilarating Elocution
ratingDescription: Sorcery speed really makes me a lot less exhilarated by this than I would be otherwise. In a deck that goes wide, this can still offer some good finishing potential, but you have to be pretty sure it's going to work before committing.

name: Expressive Iteration
ratingDescription: I really like Expressive Iteration. Early in the game, it's mostly an Anticipate, though you can try and play it without having played a land and snag a really easy two-for-one. Later in the game, it's a two-for-one every time, and all of that is a great deal for two mana.

name: Fractal Summoning
ratingDescription: Fractal Summoning is exactly the kind of Lesson you want to grab when you're flooded, and it really shows off the power of this mechanic. I want to have one of these every time I have Learn cards, and will take the first one fairly early as a result.

name: Fracture
ratingDescription: This is a straight-up sideboard card in Limited, as it misses the most important type: creatures.

name: Galazeth Prismari
ratingDescription: As far as Elder Dragons go, this isn't the bombiest. Galazeth is obviously great, as a four-mana 3/4 flyer with upside tends to be, but this plays more like a good uncommon than a mythic rare. Most games this will just be a slightly undercosted flyer that added a mana, which is good but not absurd.

name: Golden Ratio
ratingDescription: In a really creature-heavy deck, this can potentially draw you a bunch of cards, but I'm suspicious of the fail case. A card that's only good when you have a full board isn't one you can rely on, and this will fall flat too often for my tastes. I would still play it in a deck full of creatures, but it's far from a bomb.

name: Harness Infinity
ratingDescription: I'll be trying to make this work, trust me, but infinite value may actually be too much. For this to be worth seven mana, you'll need a stacked graveyard, and the casting cost is not trivial even at seven. My guess is that this is too big of an ask, even if sometimes it might draw you 10 cards.

name: Hofri Ghostforge
ratingDescription: Hofri is basically unbeatable if he stays on the board, though he's likely to die before any of your other creatures do. All your creatures now get bigger when killed, and that's not a tenable position for your opponent to be in. At 4/5, it's hard to kill this, and if they aren't able to, they likely just lose.

name: Humiliate
ratingDescription: Two mana is cheap enough that I'm willing to take the tempo hit, and the +1/+1 counter means that you're adding to the board at least a little bit. This will likely be a better turn four or five play than turn two play, as you don't want to miss out on the counter value.

name: Infuse with Vitality
ratingDescription: I'm good with this type of trick, especially if you have some nice death triggers or ETB abilities. It also lets any creature take down something big and hooks you up with a few life while it's at it.

name: Inkling Summoning
ratingDescription: This is one of the few Lessons that wouldn't be totally embarrassing to play in your main deck, though I'd try and avoid that if possible. I'm definitely interesting picking up a hybrid mana Lesson early, as it makes a lot of future learn cards into some pretty solid action.

name: Kasmina, Enigma Sage
ratingDescription: Kasmina is not where I want to be when I think of planeswalkers in Limited. She comes in and goes up to four loyalty, but doesn't protect herself very well, and making a 3/3 or 4/4 the turn after isn't impressive (nor is making a 1/1 or 2/2 the turn you cast her). The ultimate isn't great either, making this one of the weakest planeswalkers I've seen for Limited.

name: Killian, Ink Duelist
ratingDescription: You had me at lifelink and menace, though I'll take some free mana here and there as well. I wouldn't draft to try and optimize for Killian, as the ability isn't worth warping your deck around (even if it's nice when it happens). Note that it works when you target creatures on either side, so both removal and pump spells get cheaper.

name: Lorehold Apprentice
ratingDescription: I really dislike this card. It's certainly playable if you've got enough Spirits, but the recipe of “play spells plus play Spirits and get a marginal reward when you do” is not a really enticing one. Too many hoops for too little payoff, and a lot of text to get you there.

name: Lorehold Command
ratingDescription: Lorehold Command is a 3/2 that casts Lightning Helix plus some other modes, and that's a fantastic deal for five mana. Sometimes you'll want to pump your team (including giving the 3/2 you just made haste) and sometimes you'll cash in a permanent for cards, but mostly this will provide an excellent three-for-one and some life. Sounds like a deal to me.

name: Lorehold Excavation
ratingDescription: Lorehold Excavation offers a slow (very slow) way of gaining card advantage, alongside with a tiny bit of pinging and life gain. That's not going to cut it these days, and I'd really only play this if you had graveyard synergies you wanted to enable.

name: Lorehold Pledgemage
ratingDescription: Lorehold Pledgemage offers a lot of implied threat, as the opponent will rarely feel comfortable blocking this with a 3/3 or maybe even bigger. It also brawls nicely even without a spell, and is easy to cast in Lorehold decks.

name: Maelstrom Muse
ratingDescription: I love the idea of Maelstrom Muse powering out seven-drop spells, and this is the kind of card that would get me to include more of said spells (I was just looking for an excuse anyways). This is a big threat, as the opponent can't know what spells you have on deck, and a 2/4 flyer for four is good to begin with.

name: Magma Opus
ratingDescription: Besides the incredible name, this is a really strong card. Eight mana is a lot, but this should win the game every time you cast it, which is what I look for from eight drops. Plus, this format has a lot of ways to reduce its cost or otherwise cheat it out, making it more attainable than you might think at first glance.

name: Make Your Mark
ratingDescription: I'm higher on this than you might expect, mainly because it's such a cheap way to trigger magecraft. Most RW decks will be happy playing the first copy, as will any aggressive deck.

name: Manifestation Sage
ratingDescription: The Sage comes in and makes a 3/3 or 4/4 most of the time, though sometimes it'll be better or worse than that. If you know this is coming, you can refrain from playing out excess lands, and Quandrix does a good job of drawing extra cards as well.

name: Moldering Karok
ratingDescription: This is a simple card, but an effective one. It takes big bites out of the opponent and gains you a bunch of life, all while playing very nicely with ways to pump it.

name: Mortality Spear
ratingDescription: Mortality Spear is priced to move. It's fine at four mana and a steal at two, with most decks being able to gain life in some form or fashion. It even takes out other types of permanents, making it hit all the flexible and powerful notes that I'm looking for.

name: Needlethorn Drake
ratingDescription: The Simic (er, Quandrix) Doom Blade is a nice little defensive monster, and a card I'd be happy to play as many of as I can get.

name: Oggyar Battle-Seer
ratingDescription: The combination of haste and tap to scry is a funny one, as your big five-drop is full steam ahead… on scrying. Nothing here is spectacular, but the combination of reasonable size, haste and a decent ability makes this a playable.

name: Owlin Shieldmage
ratingDescription: All I can hear when I see this card is “Baby, I'm Owlin For You,” which is not actually true. A five-mana 3/3 flyer is not exciting by itself, and the opponent having to pay three life to target this doesn't make it a bomb all of a sudden. I'd play this as the high end of the curve in an aggro deck, and largely avoid it otherwise.

name: Pest Summoning
ratingDescription: This is a rare lesson (actually, it's common) that is more than fine to main-deck. It'll be interesting where you want to put this, as two Pests for three mana is a good deal for any GB deck.

name: Practical Research
ratingDescription: It's not hard to imagine discarding an instant or sorcery most of the time in a Prismari deck, and even if you have to discard two, you still got pretty good value. I'm willing to do more research, but this looks good to me even without it.

name: Prismari Apprentice
ratingDescription: Prismari Apprentice is a two-drop that always stays relevant, and sometimes even grows into a 3/3 or 4/4. That's a good deal, and a card I'm always happy to pick early and play.

name: Prismari Command
ratingDescription: This is mostly Shock-plus-Careful Study, which isn't bad as far as three-mana spells go. You won't get to blow up artifacts all that often and making Treasure isn't super exciting, but having the option to do all these things makes Prismari Command a strong inclusion to any deck.

name: Prismari Pledgemage
ratingDescription: In an aggressive deck, this will be a little bit awkward, as you won't want to main phase spells every time you want to attack. I still think you'll play it basically every time in Prismari, as it's always castable and you'll have plenty of spells to trigger it, making it a great curve-filler.

name: Quandrix Apprentice
ratingDescription: This is one of the best Apprentices, as it can reliably pick up extra lands and make sure you have all you need to get up to the eight mana that Quandrix desires.

name: Quandrix Command
ratingDescription: The two modes I'm looking at are bounce a creature and put two +1/+1 counters on a creature. That adds up to a fantastic combat trick, where you win a fight decisively and bounce their biggest creature at the time. The other two modes are a little weaker, but still will come up from time to time, making this as flexible as you'd expect a Command to be.

name: Quandrix Cultivator
ratingDescription: This doesn't fix your mana all that well, thanks to the casting cost, but I'll definitely take a 3/4 plus a ramp spell. It's a burly two-for-one that gets you ahead on lands – what more can you ask for?

name: Quandrix Pledgemage
ratingDescription: Quandrix Pledgemage fits into a bunch of different decks nicely, and offers a permanent bonus from doing what this set heavily wants you to do – cast a bunch of spells. That's a great deal, and this is a card that will go early.

name: Quintorius, Field Historian
ratingDescription: In a deck with enough Tome Shredders and the like, this is a huge beating (one could even say Elephant-sized). It can make a steady stream of Spirits while pumping them, and will be a must-kill from the opponent's perspective.

name: Radiant Scrollwielder
ratingDescription: I am in to spin the wheel. This effectively draws you a spell plus the mana to cast it every turn, even if it's at random, which will take over the game. Giving your spells lifelink is just the cherry on top.

name: Reconstruct History
ratingDescription: Not bringing back creatures makes this way too situational. It does trigger “leaves the graveyard” cards, but trying to line that up won't happen often.

name: Relic Sloth
ratingDescription: Relic Sloth is a bit dorky, but if you're missing a five-drop, get this slowpoke in there. It's hard to block and plays defense, so you definitely could do worse.

name: Returned Pastcaller
ratingDescription: A huge flyer that also draws you a card sounds good to me, and this even picks up Spirits alongside spells.

name: Rip Apart
ratingDescription: All I can hear when I see this is “You're tearing me apart, Lisa!” which is further proof this is a powerful piece of sorcery. This is efficient, flexible and powerful, making it the Certified Dream.

name: Rise of Extus
ratingDescription: I'll take a two-for-one, even if it costs a lot of mana. Rise of Extus kills their best creature, eats a card in their bin and draws you a Lesson (or lets you rummage). That's a good deal for six mana, even if you can't play more than one or maybe two of these in most decks.

name: Rootha, Mercurial Artist
ratingDescription: I'm a fan of Rootha, and I'd say that you'll always be happy to have this in your deck (in fact, I'd consider passing it to be a Roothless move). Rootha blocks well enough, and later in the game lets you spend mana to effectively draw extra cards, which is a great combination.

name: Rushed Rebirth
ratingDescription: Rushed Rebirth is too situational for my tastes. You need a creature to die, to have mana up and to have a cheaper creature that's worth getting. If you have a really powerful two or three-drop and a lot of creatures that cost more, I could see this, but I'd need to try it before recommending it.

name: Shadewing Laureate
ratingDescription: The joke here is that BW decks make a lot of 2/1 flying tokens, so the Shadewing generates a lot of +1/+1 counters. This saying “another” and not triggering of its own death is a big miss, and overall this is likely to get maybe one trigger per game. That doesn't make it too exciting, even if flyer-heavy decks will be satisfied with it.

name: Shadrix Silverquill
ratingDescription: Shadrix is a beating. While you do have to share the wealth, you have a lot of control over how good the trigger is (and if it's not good enough, you can just decline to use it). The most common things to give the opponent will be +1/+1 counters when they have a weak board or an extra card when you're beating them down. I don't think you'll want to give them a 2/1 very often, but the other two modes don't seem too bad. Oh, Shadrix is also a 2/5 flyer with double strike, so you get a huge body as well.

name: Silverquill Apprentice
ratingDescription: Being able to pump any creature makes this magecraft trigger pretty good, as it amplifies combat tricks and lets you get in for extra damage fairly easily. I'd look to combine this with flyers, double strikers and cheap cantrips for maximum effectiveness.

name: Silverquill Command
ratingDescription: The floor of making them sac a creature and draw a card is a high one, and this has a lot more flexibility than that. Sometimes you'll fly over for lethal, sometimes you'll bring back a two-drop and no matter what, you'll get value.

name: Silverquill Pledgemage
ratingDescription: I'm happy with the options the Pledgemage gives me. I can either fly over for extra damage or pick lifelink and trade off plus gain some life, and both options didn't cost me a whole lot. You do need some spells to trigger this, but even four or five is enough to make it worth playing.

name: Silverquill Silencer
ratingDescription: At 3/2 for two, you don't need to do much more for Silverquill Silencer to make the cut. This is much better in Best-of-Three, as you can name cards you know are in their deck, but even in Best-of-One you can usually just name good commons of their colors and make this a minor annoyance.

name: Spectacle Mage
ratingDescription: Prismari likes a spectacle, and this fits nicely in with the overcosted spells gang. If you have nothing this reduces, it's still a Wind Drake, but I suspect most decks will get a mana from this every now and then, which is all you really need.

name: Spirit Summoning
ratingDescription: Spirit Summoning is another valuable Lesson – not a card I want main deck, but one I'm happy to pull out of the sideboard at low cost.

name: Spiteful Squad
ratingDescription: Mean Girls (which has to be the nickname for this card) is going to provide a lot of value. You trade these off for anything you want and get two counters out of the deal, which is awesome.

name: Square Up
ratingDescription: This is a poor combat trick, even if it does give a Fractal +4/+4. Situational Titanic Growth is not something I'm interested in.

name: Stonebound Mentor
ratingDescription: Scry 1 isn't the biggest reward, but a 3/3 for three doesn't need much to make the cut (though it does need a little something, since it's tough out there for vanilla creatures these days).

name: Teach by Example
ratingDescription: I'm going to teach by example and strive never to include this in my deck. Copying spells are almost always just abysmal because they have low upside and high downside. They're very situational and when they do work, you aren't really getting away with anything.

name: Tend the Pests
ratingDescription: At a baseline, this isn't worth it. To get good value, you have to eat something big (a motto I live by), and that makes this a pretty costly proposition. It does shine in sacrifice-heavy decks that use the Pests well, and is a great response to removal, so there are decks that'll want this. Bonus points for combining it with Daemogoth Titan.

name: Thrilling Discovery
ratingDescription: I like cards that cycle through your deck more than normal in this set, mainly because of how much magecraft rewards playing extra spells. This even gains two life while you're at it, making it at least a Mildly Exciting Discovery.

name: Vanishing Verse
ratingDescription: Even though this misses plenty of cards, it's still two mana for an instant-speed removal spell, so I'm not complaining.

name: Velomachus Lorehold
ratingDescription: As long as you have a decent amount of spells in your deck, Velomachus is top-top. This may cost seven, but it nearly wins the game on the spot, giving you a 5/5 flyer with haste and vigilance to smash them, remain back to block and cast a spell immediately.

name: Witherbloom Apprentice
ratingDescription: GB aren't the typical spell colors, but this trigger is good enough that I'm happy with the Apprentice regardless. It won't be hard to get a couple pings off this, and it'll threaten the opponent for as long as it stays on the battlefield.

name: Witherbloom Command
ratingDescription: These effects are all minor, but four minor effects still adds up to a nice selection, and most of the time the best two of them will be worth more than the two mana you paid. I suspect this will most commonly be used to kill a two-drop and draw a land, but the possibilities are endless.

name: Witherbloom Pledgemage
ratingDescription: This is an easy-to-cast 5/5 that gains you a couple life (and then triggers your life gain payoffs). That works for me, especially after seeing how well Grizzled Outrider did in Kaldheim.

name: Zimone, Quandrix Prodigy
ratingDescription: Zimone is best in a long game, but the ramp aspect helps draw out the game and move it in that direction. I wouldn't play this in an aggro deck, but Quandrix isn't really set up to do that very often as is.

name: Biblioplex Assistant
ratingDescription: I really don't like the idea of playing a 2/1 flyer for four just to get a card neutral way of getting a spell back. This is too low impact to be worth it in most decks.

name: Campus Guide
ratingDescription: Don't let thoughts of Skittering Surveyor blind you too much. This is way worse, like way worse, but it's still a two-drop that ensures you hit your third land and fixes your mana, which is playable if needed.

name: Codie, Vociferous Codex
ratingDescription: I like what this has going on, but “you can't cast permanent spells” is such a brutal line of text in Limited. You just won't be able to win unless your deck is chock full of Summonings, in which case, go nuts. I do see this card as a challenge, so I'm going to try and break it if I can.

name: Cogwork Archivist
ratingDescription: This is an overcosted Spider that enables Lorehold synergies and stops death by decking. That's not really that interesting, and I'd send it back to the factory.

name: Excavated Wall
ratingDescription: Lorehold gets all the artifact toys, which makes sense. They also all suck, which is unfortunate for Lorehold. This is too low impact to be good, and note that it only mills you, not your opponent.

name: Letter of Acceptance
ratingDescription: If you need ramp and fixing, this does both, even if at a mediocre cost. It's nice that you can cash it out, and my theory is that Strixhaven students sell these on the black market to let people scam their way in.

name: Reflective Golem
ratingDescription: This mostly works with combat tricks, though the real money is combining it with fight cards. If you can pick up a couple of those, Reflective Golem goes off, and is a legit engine.

name: Spell Satchel
