ratingDescription: Spell Satchel spells disaster for anyone trying to play an efficient game, as it's really slow to get going. It won't tap for mana when you need it most, and you can't use it for mana if you ever plan on drawing cards from it.

name: Strixhaven Stadium
ratingDescription: I love the flavor of this card. It's a decent mana rock that can act as an alternate win condition, though it is tough that most decks that want a three-drop mana rock are not great at creature combat.

name: Team Pennant
ratingDescription: If you have three or more ways to make tokens, this becomes a solid playable. Otherwise, it's just too expensive to equip.

name: Zephyr Boots
ratingDescription: I really like the Boots and foresee winning a lot of games with them. Evasion plus a hit ability is really nice, and looting every turn is an easy way to win a game.

name: Access Tunnel
ratingDescription: This is basically a reward for having good mana, as it's not worth it unless you have a dual land or two. When you do, it offers a way to close out games that's hard to stop and at low cost.

name: Archway Commons
ratingDescription: I'm not a fan of this in two-color decks, which means that you mostly won't be interested.

name: The Biblioplex
ratingDescription: The majority of the power here is in using it with no cards in hand, as you should have better things to do on seven cards. Note that it effectively is surveil 1, making it powerful even with few hits in your deck.

name: Frostboil Snarl
ratingDescription: These are all good duals, and in general worth taking over midrange commons.

name: Furycalm Snarl
ratingDescription: These are all good duals, and in general worth taking over midrange commons.

name: Hall of Oracles
ratingDescription: Hall of Oracles offers some good long-term advantage, and doesn't even make you pay that big a price on colors while it's at it.

name: Lorehold Campus
ratingDescription: Tacking on scry 1 is a big improvement, and the Campuses are above many of the good commons as a result.

name: Necroblossom Snarl
ratingDescription: These are all good duals, and in general worth taking over midrange commons.

name: Prismari Campus
ratingDescription: Tacking on scry 1 is a big improvement, and the Campuses are above many of the good commons as a result.

name: Quandrix Campus
ratingDescription: Tacking on scry 1 is a big improvement, and the Campuses are above many of the good commons as a result.

name: Shineshadow Snarl
ratingDescription: These are all good duals, and in general worth taking over midrange commons.

name: Silverquill Campus
ratingDescription: Tacking on scry 1 is a big improvement, and the Campuses are above many of the good commons as a result.

name: Vineglimmer Snarl
ratingDescription: These are all good duals, and in general worth taking over midrange commons.

name: Witherbloom Campus
ratingDescription: Tacking on scry 1 is a big improvement, and the Campuses are above many of the good commons as a result.

name: Tanazir Quandrix
ratingDescription: Tanazir is a huge threat, and even gives you some value right away (assuming you've got something with counters on it). A 4/4 flyer that also casts a semi-Overrun is awesome, and this has definitely earned the title of Elder Dragon.

name: Academic Probation
ratingDescription: Even as Lessons go, this is a poor one – no wonder whoever learned it is on academic probation. Stopping a spell for a turn (and not even one they're guaranteed to have in their hand) is abysmal, and locking down a permanent for a turn isn't all that much better. While it may be free to have this in your sideboard, you shouldn't take it over just about anything relevant.

name: Devastating Mastery
ratingDescription: I'm not a fan of Devastating Mastery. It costs quad white and six mana total, which is a stretch, which means that in some games, you'll really want to play your sweeper and just be unable to. Of course, you can then play it for 2WW instead, but at that point they get their best two things back. I don't find either situation compelling and would advise that you leave this one in the board.

name: Leonin Lightscribe
ratingDescription: Now this is magecrafting. Leonin Lightscribe can lead to disgusting turns, as any time you trigger this more than once I imagine you very nearly end the game. It does lead you down the path of wanting lots of creatures and lots of spells, but I'm sure that isn't too hard to balance since most combinations will work out nicely.

name: Semester's End
ratingDescription: As fun as graduating might be, this card doesn't do a whole lot in Limited. It's expensive, so it's not a great reactive trick, and putting a +1/+1 counter on your team isn't super exciting. It can get interesting in a deck full of ETB abilities, so keep that in mind for the rare times when it applies.

name: Poet's Quill
ratingDescription: The combination of a powerful lifelink equipment and learning makes this a high pick, especially for decks that can churn out a lot of midsize or evasive creatures. Assaulting the opponent with reams of bad poetry seems flavorful, and who wouldn't get worn down by that?

name: Blot Out the Sky
ratingDescription: There's no mana cost where this is bad, and once you start going above five, it becomes truly great. You even get the bonus of blowing up noncreature permanents at eight mana, not that you need it for this to be awesome.

name: Elemental Expressionist
ratingDescription: This is a lot of words to say “you get a 4/4 when your creature dies,” which isn't the worst magecraft trigger. Assuming you're in blue-red, this is a 4/4 for four that you can always cast, and the trigger can get you a lot of extra value. I'm in.

name: Venerable Warsinger
ratingDescription: This has a lot of text, but it's mostly a 3/3 vigilance. The opponent will do their best to block it, so you aren't getting the trigger all that often, and even then you need a creature in your bin for it to work. That said, there's a lot of threatening upside here and it really goes off with combat tricks, so this will do work even if that's just drawing out good removal or awkward blocks.

name: Weather the Storm
ratingDescription: Strict life gain falls short as usual, but there is a possibility that you want this in a heavy magecraft deck (if such a thing ever comes together).

name: Tezzeret's Gambit
ratingDescription: This being effectively colorless is neat, and proliferate actually works well in Silverquill decks. I'm willing to speculate on Gambit early, since there's no real downside for taking a colorless card.

name: Gift of Estates
ratingDescription: This doesn't always work, but the good news is that it works when you need it to. It's still just lands in hand, so it's not super exciting, but you know what they say about looking gift estates in the mouth.

name: Electrolyze
ratingDescription: Electrolyze is a sweet three-for-one in the right scenario (though two-for-one is the most likely outcome). That's a great deal for just three mana, and I doubt I'll be passing this very often.

name: Channel
ratingDescription: It would take a really strange deck before I'd be interested in Channel, as adding a ton of colorless mana after an initial investment in double-green isn't that good. I will say that it'll be hard for me to resist playing this if I have Crackle with Power, but not because I think it's the right play.

name: Sign in Blood
ratingDescription: If your deck can swing double-black early, Sign in Blood is a solid playable. It's not worth stretching your mana base over, so it's not a card I'm signing up for early.

name: Compulsive Research
ratingDescription: Research is three mana for three cards, and the price of discarding a land is not a high one. Every now and then you'll discard two cards instead, but that's a rare occurrence.

name: Brainstorm
ratingDescription: In the vast majority of cases, this is a one-mana cycling card. You won't have a shuffle effect, so it won't actually accomplish much. That said, it's not very costly to include, and if you care about magecraft, this isn't a bad way to trigger it.

name: Abundant Harvest
ratingDescription: Abundant Harvest has super-cycling, where you always draw the type of card you're looking for. This finds lands early and action late, making it a card I'm always going to play.

name: Lightning Helix
ratingDescription: Lightning Helix is one of the most efficient cards ever made, and remains excellent in Limited. It's a six-point life swing for just two mana, and often kills a three or four-drop and gains you a good chunk of life.

name: Teferi's Protection
ratingDescription: Saving yourself for a turn is cool, but it doesn't really get you ahead. If you were going to die, you probably still are, so unless you're in a race, this only prolongs the inevitable.

name: Demonic Tutor
ratingDescription: I'm normally not a big fan of Tutor effects, but the difference between two mana and four mana is huge. This lets you double up on your bombs and find your situational cards, all for just two mana. I'm high on DT, and am likely to take it early every time I see it.

name: Putrefy
ratingDescription: Putrefy is about as good as it gets when it comes to removal, and even snipes artifacts as well. This is a gold card I don't mind committing to immediately.

name: Primal Command
ratingDescription: Primal Command is a nice five-drop, as it gives you a lot of awesome options. The most common pair of modes will be to put one of their lands on top and search for a creature, but gaining life is great when you need it as well. In a super lategame scenario, reshuffling even becomes relevant, making this a great card at any stage in the game.

name: Blue Sun's Zenith
ratingDescription: Having a BSZ in your deck gives you a lot of inevitability. First of all, firing this off as a six-mana draw three helps you win a control game, and second, having it as an eventual win condition means you can't lose any game that goes super deep.

name: Natural Order
ratingDescription: It's exceedingly difficult to get an advantage out of this in Limited, as you won't have big enough creatures on a reliable basis. I could see there being a deck with a couple of six or seven mana plays and a lot of Pest makers that makes use of Natural Order, but wouldn't advise slamming this first.

name: Tainted Pact
ratingDescription: Tainted Pact is a mediocre Impulse because you basically have to stop as soon as you hit a land – save this one for Constructed.

name: Lightning Bolt
ratingDescription: Nothing matches the raw efficiency of Lightning Bolt – three damage for one mana is literally as good as it gets. If you see this, you're likely taking it.

name: Agonizing Remorse
ratingDescription: Two-mana hand disruption is pretty good in general, and this even exiles for your trouble. This isn't a bomb, but definitely worth playing.

name: Gods Willing
ratingDescription: Saving your creature for just one mana is a pretty good deal, especially when you get a scry tacked on as well. This can also make your creature unblockable if they only have one color of blockers, which is a pretty sweet addition.

name: Divine Gambit
ratingDescription: As we've seen in Kaldheim, this works well in aggressive decks and poorly in most control decks. If the opponent is nearly empty-handed, it's a two-mana removal spell, but when things go wrong, they go really wrong.

name: Duress
ratingDescription: Duress is strictly a sideboard card, and a fairly weak one at that. Missing on creatures is too brutal, and this is a hideously bad top-deck.

name: Day of Judgment
ratingDescription: Four mana is the right price for a Wrath, and this being in the Mystical Archive means that it's even less likely your opponent will play around it. This is at its best in control decks obviously, but is cheap enough that I'd just play it in any white deck and have the ability to ambush my opponent.

name: Negate
ratingDescription: Negate is the perfect sideboard card and not something I tend to main-deck (except in Sealed).

name: Shock
ratingDescription: Shock is always fine and never exciting, and gets a little bit of extra juice if you've got some magecraft cards.

name: Tendrils of Agony
ratingDescription: As much as I like drafting Storm, normal Limited is not the place to do it.

name: Chaos Warp
ratingDescription: I'm not a fan of Chaos Warp. Flipping their top card and giving it to them if it's a permanent isn't a good deal, especially since most Limited decks are like three-fourths permanents (if not more).

name: Time Warp
ratingDescription: You might think that Time Warp is awesome in Limited, but I'm unfortunately here to tell you that it's just okay. It mostly cycles and gets you an extra land drop, as setting it up to get multiple good attacks in a row is fairly rare. It's not costly to include or anything, it just isn't a windmill slam bomb or even close.

name: Increasing Vengeance
ratingDescription: In a deck with a bunch of cheap spells, this does have a chance to really pop off. You copy one spell early for two mana, and much later in the game this acts as a finisher for seven to nine mana. That's interesting, and could be worth a slot in something like a Prismari deck.

name: Dark Ritual
ratingDescription: I'm not a fan of Dark Ritual in Limited, mainly because throwing away a card to play something a little sooner is just not going to pay dividends most of the time. Every now and then this can lead to a sweet play, but for the most part it's worse than just playing a basic land.

name: Infuriate
ratingDescription: If you want a combat trick, you've got one. This is nothing to write home about, but does get the job done.

name: Thrill of Possibility
ratingDescription: If you have room for some card filtering, this does the job. It's not particularly advantageous, but it can help deal with flood/screw well enough.

name: Ephemerate
ratingDescription: Add in a couple nice ETB abilities and Ephemerate becomes a very effective card. For only one mana, you get multiple flicker effects, which can be awesome in the right deck.

name: Doom Blade
ratingDescription: To think, this once was a common. Doom Blade is so efficient that it gets a 4.0, as killing anything for two mana is really hard to beat.

name: Mizzix's Mastery
ratingDescription: I really like this in a Prismari deck that has a couple of the expensive spells you can discard for Treasures. It's a one-two punch that gets you a seven-mana spell for just four mana, which can lead to absurd games. Making two 4/4's on turn three is a possibility, and this is a sweet build-around because of plays like that.

name: Mind's Desire
ratingDescription: As cool as this is to build around in Constructed, it's a total blank in Limited.

name: Memory Lapse
ratingDescription: Memory Lapse, on the other hand, only requires a single blue, and that's a big difference. It buys you a turn against anything, and can really wreck situational cards. Imagine putting a combat trick back on top, winning that combat, and being able to play around it in the future.

name: Harmonize
ratingDescription: Four mana for three cards is not a deal I'm passing on often, and Harmonize fits neatly into the game plan of both green schools.

name: Opt
ratingDescription: Like all the other cantrips on the list, this is fine if you have room for it, but nothing special if you don't.

name: Defiant Strike
ratingDescription: Defiant Strike is always playable, but never all that exciting. If you have some decent magecraft triggers, it's worth a slot, but otherwise usually doesn't make the cut.

name: Growth Spiral
ratingDescription: Growth Spiral is a painless way to accelerate to your expensive cards, and even in the lategame it gets you your card back. Quandrix is definitely going to like this one.

name: Regrowth
ratingDescription: Like Demonic Tutor, this is a cheap enough that I like it a lot more than I usually like this kind of effect. At two mana, you feel pretty good about getting back whatever you need to, and I'm okay paying a little bit of a tax for this much flexibility.

name: Cultivate
ratingDescription: Cultivate is a two-for-one that ramps you and fixes your colors, making it a fantastic early pickup. It fits perfectly into Quandrix, but will obviously be good in Witherbloom as well.

name: Faithless Looting
ratingDescription: Looting puts you down a card, and even with flashback, you still end up on the bad end of the deal. Magecraft isn't enough to make this worth it – don't let its Constructed applications make it look stronger than it is.

name: Grapeshot
ratingDescription: Grapeshot isn't too hard to line up as the second spell in a turn, making it into a Forked Bolt of sorts. Add that to the possibility of maybe dealing three at times and you have a card that's playable in a deck with enough cheap spells.

name: Despark
ratingDescription: This doesn't hit everything, but it does hit the things you care most about killing. That's good enough for me, and I'd always play it.

name: Eliminate
ratingDescription: This misses a lot of the creatures you care most about killing, but it's still cheap enough to be a premium piece of removal. Don't be too picky – this gets worse the longer the game goes on.

name: Swords to Plowshares
ratingDescription: Swords is the most efficient removal spell in the history of the game, and if you're lucky enough to open it, you should take it. Giving the opponent a little life is such a minor drawback compared to the upside of this costing one mana – there's a reason this is such an iconic card in Magic's history.

name: Inquisition of Kozilek
ratingDescription: Inquisition is a solid addition to any deck, even with the risk of missing. It's cheap enough that it's easy to take a turn off to cast it, and will hit almost all the time when drawn early.

name: Urza's Rage
ratingDescription: Paying the kicker cost is unlikely to ever happen, but three for three is still a decent ratio. I'd be happy enough with this as a midrange burn spell, and there is a dream to be had here…

name: Snakeskin Veil
ratingDescription: Snakeskin Veil plays out pretty well in a creature-heavy deck, though it can be lacking if they don't have much removal. Either way, it's not a premium card, despite the fancy art.

name: Village Rites
ratingDescription: In a deck full of sac fodder, Village Rites is a fine playable. It'll make the cut in most Witherbloom decks, and even Silverquill won't mind it given enough Summonings.

name: Approach of the Second Sun
ratingDescription: In a dedicated control deck, Approach of the Second Sun can be an effective finisher. It gains you seven life and puts them on a relatively fast clock, especially if you have any card draw. It's not a bomb, but it can fill out a deck nicely.

name: Claim the Firstborn
ratingDescription: There isn't support for a red/X sacrifice deck in Strixhaven, so Claim the Firstborn lacks a good home. Otherwise it would be solid, but as is it doesn't really fit anywhere.

name: Adventurous Impulse
ratingDescription: This is a much less powerful version of the same effect, where you get a little bit of selection but run the risk of missing when you really need something.

name: Mana Tithe
ratingDescription: I love me a good Mana Tithe, and would happily play this in any base white deck. The best thing is, if you get them with it in game one, they will play scared the whole rest of the match.

name: Crux of Fate
ratingDescription: Unless you're lucky enough to pick up an Elder Dragon, this is basically just a five-mana Wrath. That's still a good card, and one that you can plan a game around easily.

name: Stone Rain
ratingDescription: Don't talk yourself into this – it won't end well. Blowing up lands is a Constructed thing, and not something that works in Limited.

name: Whirlwind Denial
ratingDescription: This is a sideboard card against huge bombs, and not much else. A three-mana counter that sometimes goes dead in the lategame is not what I'm looking for.

name: Krosan Grip
ratingDescription: This is a sideboard card – a very fast sideboard card, but a sideboard card nonetheless. There is something comforting about split second, since you know they can't do anything about it, but it's not like your Naturalizes get countered all that often anyways.

name: Revitalize
ratingDescription: If you need life gain or want extra spell triggers, this does the job, but most decks simply won't have room for such a minor effect (even if it does replace itself).

name: Strategic Planning
ratingDescription: I've been largely unimpressed with Strategic Planning, as two mana is a lot more than one for an effect that doesn't accomplish much.

name: Counterspell
ratingDescription: Counterspell isn't as good in Limited as you might expect, given its Constructed prowess. It turns out that assembling UU is not trivial, and leaving mana up for a counter is still somewhat costly. That said, this is still a good card in any heavy blue deck, just not something to slam early.
